com.facebook.buck.core.graph.transformation

Class DefaultAsyncTransformationEngine<ComputeKey,ComputeResult>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.facebook.buck.core.graph.transformation.DefaultAsyncTransformationEngine<ComputeKey,ComputeResult>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    AsyncTransformationEngine<ComputeKey,ComputeResult>

    public final class DefaultAsyncTransformationEngine<ComputeKey,ComputeResult>
extends Object
implements AsyncTransformationEngine<ComputeKey,ComputeResult>
    Transformation engine that transforms supplied ComputeKey into ComputeResult via AsyncTransformer. This engine is able to asynchronously run graph based computation, reusing results when possible. Note that the computation graph must be an acyclic graph.

    This engine is able to deal with dependencies in the computation graph by having Transformer request dependent results of other transformations through TransformationEnvironment.evaluate(Object, Function) or TransformationEnvironment.evaluateAll(Iterable, Function).

    The transformation is incremental, so cached portions of the transformation will be used whenever possible based on ComputeKey.equals(). Therefore, ComputeKey should be immutable, and have deterministic equals. For future perspective, we want to have ComputeKey be serializable, so that we can eventually send keys to be computed remotely.

    A custom cache can be supplied to the engine to cache the computation as desired.

    Transformations will be applied asynchronously, so independent transformations can be executed in parallel. It is therefore important that transformations are thread safe.

    Transformations also should never block waiting for Futures. Hence, Transformations can only access the Future results through CompletionStage as opposed to Future, which only has async methods exposed. It is strongly suggested to use the async versions of all methods on the CompletionStage to allow Java to perform the transformation in any executor.

    By using all callback based operations and being tail recursive, this engine will also reduce stack usage, eliminating stack overflow for large graph computations. The TransformationEnvironment has every method implemented as non-blocking, and returns a Future of the dependency calculation such that if Transformer is implemented to be tail recursive, the whole graph computation will be tail recursive, eliminating stack use.

    Currently, we only use the engine for TargetGraph to ActionGraph, but theoretically this can be extended to work with any computation.

        Constructs a DefaultAsyncTransformationEngine with an internal cache that uses the ComputeKey for reusability.
        Parameters:
        transformer - the AsyncTransformer this engine executes
        estimatedNumOps - the estimated number of operations this engine will execute given a computation, to reserve the size of its computation index
